name: applications
text: <@U11MANG9G|jonathanlevi> has renamed the channel from "business-applications" to "applications"

purpose: This channel's purpose is mainly for discussing/addressing (business and community-related) applications
text: <@U11MANG9G|jonathanlevi> set the channel purpose: This channel's purpose is mainly for discussing/addressing (business and community-related) applications
<@U11MANG9G|jonathanlevi> set the channel topic: (business and community-related) applications

first question for the channel: i have some questions on building the right chaincode, is that considered part of this channel’s purpose? i suspect in many cases building an application involves building both the chaincode and code that acts on the user’s behalf ("application code?")

if answer is yes, here’s my question on the chaincode: what’s the requirements on building the right chaincode? guess some of the most obvious ones include the code must be executable without extra state that has to be acquired out-of-band like credentials to external APIs? what about idempotency?
Hi <@U13TWBRBL>. Yes, we haven't done enough work on describing the purpose of this channel in detail (yet).
It depends also on the definitions/semantics/logical separation of what belongs to the application layer part of the stack.
Other than just reply to you with generalities/guidelines - do you have a specific application in mind?
It will probably be easier to talk about the 'right' code, knowing more of what you are looking to build.

so let’s use a hypothetical scenario: 3 banks participate in a blockchain network, each having their own validating peer, now a chaincode is deployed to the network and they need to execute and validate, let’s say the code calls an external API owned by a private financial services company for, i don’t know, getting the current exchange rate. this service API is obviously protected so the caller must pass along a valid credential to access it (let’s say it’s oauth based so the expected credential is an access token).

it’s not clear to me whether it’s legitimate to ask each validator to use their own credentials to access the API, which could result in discrepancies if, say, the API has pricing tiers tied to timeliness of the returned quote and all banks have not purchased the same pricing tier.

<@U13TWBRBL>: while I don’t believe the current environment is actually locked down to prevent chaincode from reaching outside, architecturally I think it is intended that chaincode can only react to invoke/queries
there is some ongoing work to have specially privileged chaincode that can reach outside, but there are a bunch of advanced considerations to make that happen
normal chaincode should be thought of as pure functions that are approximately S’ = f(M, S)
or, a collection of pure functions is a more accurate description

<@U0KPFAZNF>: I’m very interested in the ongoing work you referred to above, I assume that includes the identity WG’s effort to figure out identity for enrollment vs. transactions, and access control based on pseudonymity?
<@U13TWBRBL>: no, nothing to do with identity or AAA

i just meant that #1 chaincode needs to be deterministic, and #2 the validator needs to protect itself from malicious/broken chaincode, and that implies its probably unwise to let chaincode access the network
<@U0ULK2JPP> put the ground-work down for the system chaincode which should have enhanced priviledge here <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/pull/1192>

attachments.title: System Chaincode Implementation - v2  by muralisrini · Pull Request #1192 · hyperledger/fabric · GitHub
attachments.text: The PR implements <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/wiki/System-Chaincode-Specification>. NOTE - The difference between v1 and current version is moving SYSTEM type from protos.ChaincodeSpec to...
attachments.fallback: GitHub: System Chaincode Implementation - v2  by muralisrini · Pull Request #1192 · hyperledger/fabric

text: I misunderstood when you said "specially privileged chaincode”, guess you meant the system chaincode with elevated privilege, but not for application-level chaincode.
guess I’m trying to figure out if there are legit business scenarios that would require (or best served) by the chaincode making calls to external APIs

after validating my thoughts with my colleagues, it appears everyone agrees that it doesn’t make sense for chaincode to make external API call or for that matter doing anything that would introduce non-determinism.
Not taking sides here :wink:, but there could be a few cases when some form of 'external' API needed... for example, interactions with an "Oracle" might be one.
I do agree that keeping a self-contained code is much cleaner! But it might also depend on the applications.
There are several ideas out there for those particular cases, but generally speaking vanilla chaincode should not be able to break isolation IMO
<@U0KPFAZNF>: Yes, that's the much preferable approach.
(Similar to what <@U13TWBRBL> was highlighting) mostly, being able to control the 'state', and not rely on externals.
for any given message M and state S, we want S’ = f(M,S) where S’ is deterministic
thats harder to do if f() can reach outside the machine
not to mention dangerous to the host :wink:
Sure, what I wanted to just mention above are applications that do require some events or triggers or external input (that affect state).
totally agree, but those have to be implemented carefully
Think about a contract that triggers something if AAPL price goes above or below some level.
and probably not via something that just anyone can deploy
yes i understand what you are driving at completely, just saying that assuming user deployed chaincode may fulfill that role is problematic

On that note, I usually like signed/endorsed market data/external events - so that we don't agree to a contract (which we control), but then can 'tamper' with it, by letting other control the input (outside our control).
that is how it is typically solved, yes
I am beginning to love this channel :wink:
Mind you, I intend to start a document that we'll share here with groups/types of applications that we should discuss.
This should drive/highlight some requirements, help us to identity the state of the 'current' HL code, what's supported, what's ongoing, what people need, etc.
I looked at example06 in the fabric project.
It looked like an Invoke function.
How was the Run function called?
Run() was split into Init()/Invoke().  I suspect the example wasn't ported
<@U11TAFPUP>: the “Run()” method is just a dispatcher
In the old ABI, the init/ctor was tunneled as a standard txn, but that has obvious issues so it was split into first class function
it takes the “Function:” property in the POST message and routes to “init”, “invoke” or “query” methods
in later versions you don’t need to write the “Run()” any longer (as <@U0KPFAZNF> said)
I want to write example that looks like a financial exchange using multi signature.
A stock is received successfully if there are both signatures from the seller and the broker.
How does a multi signatures application look in chaincode?
i envision it as a combination of ACLs+FSM
obviously that relates to ACL but isnt an ACL per se
Could you give me some details or references? and FSM = Finite State Machine?
im just saying that take the components available: you have a KV-state, an RPC-like interface to it, and an (emerging) ability to associate RPC caller with TCert identity
from there, I would model a multi-sig as an FSM in the kv-state triggered by the inbound identity/RPCs as events for machine state advancement
e.g. a two party multi-sig would perhaps have an FSM with states [IDLE, PARTYA, PARTYB, COMPLETE]
or perhaps more clearly: [INCOMPLETE, PARTYA_NOTB, PARTYB_NOTA, COMPLETE]
many ways to solve it, but that is how I would tend to approach it
I post the question on SO for some ones want to share thier ideas.

attachments.title: How to write a multi-sign application using chaincode
attachments.text: I want to write a financial exchange example. A stock is received successfully if there are signatures from both the seller and the broker. Could you share some ideas to do it with chaincode?

text: i have a chaincode deployed on all the nodes as a container. Now that i have updated some logic (another version) of same chaincode.. is there a way i can remove the chaincode deployed in hyperledger and redeploy the new chaincode ??
is that the way it works
I believe you can kill the docke rinstance running it, but my understanding is that the code is mined and added to the blockchain
when you deploy you will get a hash
and next invocation will need to use the new hash

Yup. Sorry. Nothing “official” and since people download it and deploy locally, we have no real way to know.
